video.title: Algorithms and Data Structures Tutorial - Full Course for Beginners
video.description:
In this course you will learn about algorithms and data structures, two of the fundamental topics in computer science. There are three main parts to this course: algorithms, data structures, and a deep dive into sorting and searching algorithms.

By the end, you will understand what algorithms and data structures are, how they are measured and evaluated, and how they are used to solve problems.

This course was developed by Pasan Premaratne and Jay McGavren. It was made possible by a grant from teamtreehouse.com

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Introduction to Algorithms
⌨️ (1:57:44) Introduction to Data Structures
⌨️ (4:11:02) Algorithms: Sorting and Searching

⭐️ Code Snippets for Course ⭐️
💻 Introduction to Algorithms:
⌨️ Algorithms in Code:
🔗 Linear Search Implementations: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-algorithms/algorithms-in-code/linear-search-implementations
🔗 Binary Search Implementations: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-algorithms/algorithms-in-code/binary-search-implementations

💻 Introduction to Data Structures
⌨️ Exploring Arrays:
🔗 Array Characteristics and Storage: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/exploring-arrays/array-characteristics-and-storage
🔗 Operations on Arrays: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/exploring-arrays/operations-on-arrays

⌨️ Building a Linked List:
🔗 Singly and Doubly Linked Lists: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/building-a-linked-list/singly-and-doubly-linked-lists-2
🔗 Linked List Operations: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/building-a-linked-list/linked-lists-operations

⌨️ The Merge Sort Algorithm:
🔗 Merge Sort Implementations: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/the-merge-sort-algorithm/merge-sort-implementations
🔗 Alternate Versions of Merge Sort: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/the-merge-sort-algorithm/alternate-versions-of-merge-sort 

⌨️ Merge Sort and Linked Lists:
🔗 Implementing Merge Sort on Linked Lists: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/introduction-to-data-structures/merge-sort-and-linked-lists/implementing-merge-sort-on-linked-lists

💻 Algorithms: Sorting and Searching
⌨️ Sorting Algorithms:
🔗 Code for Bogosort: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/algorithms-sorting-and-searching/sorting-algorithms/code-for-bogosort
🔗 Code for Selection Sort: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/algorithms-sorting-and-searching/sorting-algorithms/code-for-selection-sort
🔗 Code for Quicksort: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/algorithms-sorting-and-searching/sorting-algorithms/code-for-quicksort
🔗 Code for Merge Sort: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/algorithms-sorting-and-searching/sorting-algorithms/code-for-merge-sort

⌨️ Searching Names:
🔗 Code for Linear Search: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/algorithms-sorting-and-searching/searching-names/code-for-linear-search
🔗 Code for Binary Search: https://teamtreehouse.com/library/algorithms-sorting-and-searching/searching-names/code-for-binary-search

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

topLevelComment.text:
I tried to program the insert one, and i came up with this solution :

def insert(self, data, position):

        if position == 0:
            self.add(data)
        else:
            nodes = []
            current = self.head

            while current:
                nodes.append(current)
                current = current.next_node

            new_node = Node(data)
            nodes[position - 1].next_node = new_node
            new_node.next_node = nodes[position]
            nodes.insert(position, new_node)

topLevelComment.text: In recursive binary search why we aren't subtracting 1 from midpoint in the else condition?

replies.author: Aryan
replies.text:
Because the midpoint is an index of the length of the list  divided by 2. i.e 5 which is used to return the next set of values. 

Say you have a target of 8.  the first statement checks if the target is higher than list[5] i.e. value 6.  if true then it returns values in a list[ 7,8,9,10] i.e. index 6 = 7, 7=8, 8=9, 9=10.  It then repeats the function.

 However if the target is 3, the code checks the first statement as this is not true so it goes to the else statement: 
return recursive_binary_search(list[:midpoint],target)---  here you are returning list[1,2,3,4,5,6] i.e. index 0 to 5 (see if you minus one then value 6 would be missed out and that value was not returned by the above value (7-10).  The next iteration will again half the index  and check the values and carry on if required. 

I hope this helped. Anyway you can use print statements i.e. print("Midpoint : ", midpoint, "value ", list[midpoint]) and step through the code. 
Target value :  12
Midpoint :  5 value  6
Midpoint :  2 value  9
Midpoint :  0 value  10
Target found:  False
Target value :  1
Midpoint :  5 value  6
Midpoint :  2 value  3
Midpoint :  1 value  2
Midpoint :  0 value  1
Target found:  True
If you haven't already learned to master debugging, it is very important to spend time learning it. I always use print statements to understand what's happening as I do not use an IDE that outputs the variables.

topLevelComment.author: Ramandeep Virk
topLevelComment.text:
This is the actual code for LinkedList:

class node:
    def __init__(self,data=None):
        self.data=data
        self.next=None
        
class LinkedList:
    def __init__(self):
        self.head=node()
        
    def append(self,data):
        new_node=node(data)
        curr=self.head
        while curr.next!=None:
            curr=curr.next
        curr.next=new_node
            
    def display(self):
        enteries=[]
        curr=self.head
        while curr.next!=None:
            curr=curr.next
            enteries.append(curr.data)
        print(enteries)
        
    def length(self):
        count=0
        curr=self.head
        while curr.next:
            count+=1
            curr=curr.next
        return count

Demo: 
my_list=LinkedList()
my_list.append(4)
my_list.append(8)
my_list.display()
my_list.length()

courtesy: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=JlMyYuY1aXU

topLevelComment.author: Ok Google
topLevelComment.text:
3:28:55 I assume, same pattern we saw in binary search which complexity is O(log n), but for binary search works with one part of array forgetting about the one that does not meet condition. Split function divides array into halves and then has to work with both parts splitting them into quarters and running again for_each_of_them. This does not look like O(log n) and more like O(n-1) to me for splits only.
For example, for array of 4 elements binary search will do 2 splits(4 > 2 > 1) in worst scenario, but split() function will do 3 splits(4 > 2 ,2 > 1,1,1,1). To verify, just put a global increment into your split function and print it after execution.
Now, what did I get wrong?

Hey Pasan, amazing tutorial, you made DS and algorithm so simple to understand. Thank you.
One course of correction in recursive binary search at 1:38:36, length of the new list would be 4 when target is greater than the midpoint of the original list, so the new mid point would be at position 2 which should be 6.

replies.author: Tim Han
replies.text: @StudiousPanda yea im confused as to why he omitted 5 from that new list....

replies.author: StudiousPanda
replies.text:
@Ömer Geysoğlu I don't think mid point of 2 equals to 2nd index. Basically the video is a bit confusing on this part, there are 2 ways to calculate midpoint, 
1) Using actual number of values: len(list)//2  OR 2) Using actual number of values minus 1: (len(list) - 1)//2

Since the code used the second option, let's stick to that,  first we have a test_list = [5, 6, 7, 8]
For a list of size 4, midpoint is actually (len(test_list) - 1)//2 = (4 - 1)//2 = 3//2 = 1

So the midpoint for test_list is actually test_list[1] = 6 and not 7

topLevelComment.text: It's an amazing resource and thanks for sharing it openly. My only concern is that around 1:10:45 you've created the function and passed the argument with the name "list", shadowing the built-in name. It can really mess things up inside the function scope, as "list" is a python built-in keyword used for list data structure functionalities. As python keywords should not be touched, a simple solution would be to go with a different name or use "_list" as a name to avoid confusion.

topLevelComment.author: Sam van der Stoop
topLevelComment.text: In the split function for merge sort for linked lists, you write code in case linked_list == None or linked_list.head == None. But if linked_list.head == None it will never even make it to the split function because it is handled before that in the merge sort function itself. And were linked_list == None it would never reach the split function either because the merge sort function would've crashed already trying to run linked_list.size() and linked_list.head on a None value. And because the merge sort for linked lists doesn't handle None as an argument, having split return right_side = None means the next recursive linked_list_merge_sort(right_half) would crash, too.

topLevelComment.author: kbr
topLevelComment.text:
I've been looking for a DSA course to recommend to a friend. I like the exposition, unfortunately there are some errors (at least one).
Your recursive_binary_search function (~1:30:00) has O(n) worst case time and space complexity because slicing a list copies all elements of the slice to create a new list.
The video even mentions at ~1:51:00 that you allocate additional memory of size n/2, then n/4, etc., but then incorrectly concludes that it has logarithmic time complexity.
No, it doesn't: you have to allocate n/2 + n/4 + n/8 + ... additional memory; the series n/2 + n/4 +... sums up to ~n. Thus you're allocating O(n) additional memory in total, giving us O(n) time and space complexity.
You don't even need to look at the series: the first recursive call already allocates n/2 memory, giving O(n) time/space complexity.

replies.author: Justin Cui
replies.text: no, u dont add up n, n/2, n/4... instead, each new list created takes up a constant space, and the number of lists needed to be created is log(n), therefore it is logn

topLevelComment.text:
Your implementation of merge sort also takes more than O(n) space. you're creating new lists each time.
left, right created -- n space
left, right from left created -- n/2 space (the stack still has above lists in parent function)
left, right from left from previous step created -- n/4 space
 You have to operate on original array instead of creating copies. Then I don't think the extra factor come into picture.

3:35:10 I didn't understand why you mentioned log(n) here. log(n) is just the number of levels of splitting. 8 elements means 3 levels of splitting. What do you mean by 3 space taken?? 

I understand that smaller merges at deeper levels, take less space and they build up to a max of n at the top most merge. This is confusing!

replies.text: @LUCKIΞ There are easy certs (cisco, microsoft etc) you can do in a month to get a job almost instantly if you do that after highschool provided you are already good in computer stuff you can easily outrank a college grad by the time they graduate. 5 years experience > most college BAs

replies.author: LUCKIΞ
replies.text:
A quality education can be gained online for free. I agree. However, to get a job quickly, you'd need a University Degree certificate. You can still work without it by having a strong portfolio but that's a route not everyone can able to take.
One more thing, to work in the US you'd need an H-1B visa. The first criteria to get an H-1B is to have a 4 years Bachelor degree from a reputable University which is accredited by WES.
If you do not have a degree then you'd require to have an experience of at least 12 years because the system calculates 1 year of formal degree course equivalent to 3 years of work experience.
If you apply for Canada, there's a credit based system, where you can not have sufficient credits to get eligible without a Bachelor or a Master degree. It's the fact.

replies.author: Anon Ymous
replies.text: @Zsolt B True, but the most important thing to get hired is always networking. I got 2 job offers in the past 3 months without even applying just because I knew some people who work in tech. The system sucks.

replies.author: Zsolt B
replies.text: @Anon Ymous they may suck at coding, but still they get hired easier than those without any diploma. That was the point.

replies.author: Guy with a name
replies.text:
Python will be pretty easy for you as you know c and java , you can learn the basics in about few days
1. we don't have to declare the type of variable and even the variable in python .
2. python does not use brackets it just use indentation (spaces/organization)
3. for loops in python works like "for i in arr:" just like "for (int I : arr){} " in java , to iterate from 0 to a desired number use "for i in range(your number+1):"
4. you don't have to declare main function here, to make a function you can use "def your_func:" keyword
and some google search you can able to understand some simple python program
